Metadata.Title: Use X-XSS-Protection to Prevent Reflected XSS
Metadata.DirectLink: Use X-XSS-Protection to Prevent Reflected XSS

Content.Data:
==Applies To==
* HTML5
==What to Do==
In HTML5 applications, inject the X-XSS-Protection header in the response for each page.
==Why==
For users of Internet Explorer versions 8 and above, the X-XSS-Protection response header adds an extra layer of defense against reflected cross site scripting (XSS) attacks. Note that the first layer of defense, as dictated by good coding practices, is always to sanitize all user input on the server side.
==How==
X-XSS-Protection is a nonstandard response header supported by Internet Explorer versions 8 and above. To inject the X-XSS-Protection header in the response for each page in an HTML5 application, you have three options:
# **Configure the web server to inject the header in each page response.** If you are using Apache Web Server, add the X-XSS-Protection header to the httpd.conf configuration file: {{{ Header always append X-XSS-Protection 1;mode=block }}}. Note that there is no space after the 1 in the above configuration line. Restart the web server or reload the configuration. # **Add the header response in the source code of the server-side language.** For example, in PHP, add the X-XSS-Protection header to the response. Insert it before any other code is executed in the PHP script, so that the response header will be sent before any data is sent to the browser: {{{ header("X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block"); }}} # **Create a Servlet filter in Java-based applications.** The name of the Filter class is arbitrary, but it must implement the javax.Servlet.Filter interface. The work in the Filter class is in the doFilter method. \\ {{{ public void doFilter(ServletRequest req, ServletResponse resp,FilterChain chain) throws IOException, ServletException { }}} \\ {{{ HttpServletResponse response = (HttpServletResponse) resp; }}} \\ {{{ response.addHeader(“X-XSS-Protection”,”1; mode=block”); }}} \\ {{{ chain.doFilter(req, resp); }}} \\ {{{ } }}} \\ Add the filter to the application web.xml file. The following snippet is for a filter with the class name XSSProtectionFilter: \\ {{{ <filter> }}} \\ {{{ <filter-name>XSSProtectionFilter</filter-name> }}} \\ {{{ <filter-class> }}} \\ {{{ com.example.servlet.filters.XSSProtectionFilter }}} \\ {{{ </filter-class> }}} \\ {{{ </filter> }}} \\ {{{ <filter-mapping> }}} \\ {{{ <filter-name>XSSProtectionFilter</filter-name> }}} \\ {{{ <url-pattern>/*</url-pattern> }}} \\ {{{ </filter-mapping> }}}
==Problem Example==
Example.com is a popular social media site that greets users after they log in. In this scenario, there is no input validation on the server side (though there should be). As such, Example.com is extremely vulnerable to reflected XSS attacks.
Here is a snippet of PHP code from the account.php page:
{{{ <?php $name = $_REQUEST["name"];
echo ("Hello ". $name ."!") ; }}}
A web page links to the URL http://www.example.com/account.php?name=Jane.
As the user named Jane navigates to the account.php page from the link, her name is placed into the GET request as the value of the parameter name. The PHP script sets a variable to the value of the name parameter, and displays “Hello Jane!”
The reflected XSS vulnerability can be exploited as follows:
http://www.example.com/account.php?name=<script>alert(‘gotcha’);</script> :
When the page is loaded, it renders Hello and contains a JavaScript pop-up message with “gotcha.” This harmless alert box could very well have access to the user’s cookies in the vulnerable domain or otherwise execute arbitrary JavaScript code.
The server response is:
{{{ HTTP/1.1 200 OK Date: Tue, 16 Apr 2013 05:23:17 GMT Server: Apache/2.2.16 (Win32) mod_ssl/2.2.16 OpenSSL/0.9.8o X-Powered-By: PHP/5.3.8-ZS5.5.0 ZendServer Set-Cookie: ZDEDebuggerPresent=php,phtml,php3; path=/ Keep-Alive: timeout=5, max=100 Connection: Keep-Alive Transfer-Encoding: chunked Content-Type: text/html }}} \\ ==Solution Example==
To correct the situation, Example.com developers include the X-XSS-Protection header. In the httpd.conf configuration file of their Apache Web Server 2, they add
{{{ Header always append X-XSS-Protection 1;mode=block }}}
and reload the Apache configuration.
They could achieve the same results by adding the header to the source code. For example:
{{{ <?php header("X-XSS-Protection: 1;mode=block");
$name = $_REQUEST["name"];
echo ("Hello ". $name ."!") ; }}}
Here is the server header response:
{{{ HTTP/1.1 200 OK Date: Thu, 18 Apr 2013 03:56:12 GMT Server: Apache/2.2.16 (Win32) mod_ssl/2.2.16 OpenSSL/0.9.8o X-XSS-Protection: 1;mode=block X-Powered-By: PHP/5.3.8-ZS5.5.0 ZendServer Set-Cookie: ZDEDebuggerPresent=php,phtml,php3; path=/ X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block Keep-Alive: timeout=5, max=100 Connection: Keep-Alive Transfer-Encoding: chunked Content-Type: text/html }}}
When the link {{{ http://www.example.com/account.php?name=<script>alert(‘gotcha’);</script> }}} is loaded in Internet Explorer 8, Hello will not render. Instead, the hash (#) is displayed. In addition, the browser will not execute any JavaScript code.
